title.native: ヱヴァンゲリヲン新劇場版:序

description:
After the second impact, all that remains of Japan is Tokyo-3, a city that's being attacked by giant creatures that seek to eradicate the human kind, called Angels. After not seeing his father for more than eight years, Shinji Ikari receives a phone call in which he is told to urgently come to the NERV Headquarters, an organization that deals with the destruction of the Angels through the use of giant mechs called Evas. Shinji's objective is to pilot the Eva Unit 01 while teaming up with the Eva Unit 00 pilot, Ayanami Rei.

Note: Exists in several versions, as denoted by the version number:
• 1.0: Sep 1, 2007 - Original theatrical release
• 1.01: Apr 25, 2008 - DVD release containing minor adjustments and fine tunings in picture, editing, and sound quality.
 • Explanation of Evangelion 1.01 - Included with the special edition DVD release of 1.01, overlays large captions to provide the "official designations" of people, locations, weapons, technology, and so forth.
• 1.11: May 27, 2009 - Blu-ray/DVD re-release with 3 minutes of new animation added to the first 15 minutes and fixing video issues present in the previous release.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

title.native: ヱヴァンゲリヲン新劇場版:破
ビューティフル・ワールド
新世紀エヴァンゲリオン劇場版 Air/まごころを、君に

node.description:
__Height:__ 160 cm

[Website](https://kotochawan.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/kotochawanmoon) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1bBpyzaOM0gd7SNEwpDarQ/) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kotono_Mitsuishi) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三石琴乃)

A voice actress and narrator. She graduated from high school in 1986 and then entered Katsuta Seiyuu Academy. 

In 1989, Mitsuishi made her seiyuu debut as Tomoyo in the OVA [Ace o Nerae! Final Stage](https://anilist.co/anime/312/). She became an instant celebrity with her role as [Usagi Tsukino](https://anilist.co/character/2030) when [Sailor Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/530) debuted in 1992, and her popularity increased again with her role as [Misato Katsuragi](https://anilist.co/character/1259) in the anime TV series [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30). She is considered one of the most influential seiyuu in the business; the animated adaptation of [Ebichu](https://anilist.co/anime/1060/) was largely produced because of her interest in the project, reading the manga out loud between takes of recording lines for Evangelion. Mitsuishi is a freelancer and a former member of the talent management firm Arts Vision. 

She is married and has one daughter. 

Non-anime roles:

Vulpisfoglia - Arknights (VG)
[Jade](https://anilist.co/character/355046) - Honkai: Star Rail

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/y_sadamoto)

Yoshiyuki Sadamoto is an animator, illustrator, character designer, and one of the founding members of studio Gainax.

After college, Sadamoto learned the ropes of key animation under [Yasuo Otsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/Yasuo--Otsuka) at Telecom before becoming a founding member of Gainax. Otsuka later named Sadamoto one of the three men more skillful than him. Though Sadamoto is not an unskilled animator by any means, his reputation rests mainly on his iconic character designs, evident in the reception of the Evangelion cast. Nearly all of Gainax' biggest productions have their characters designed by Sadamoto. He is one of the biggest contributors to the general look of Gainax anime and has proven to be massively influential for character designers of future generations.

Sadamoto's characters are often thin, fragile and have sharp yet understated facial features. He pays a lot of attention to fashion as well.

Most of Sadamoto's influences are mangaka such as [Katsuhiro Otomo](https://anilist.co/staff/96872/Katsuhiro-Otomo), [Yoshitaka Amano](https://anilist.co/staff/97967/Yoshitaka-Amano), [Kazuo Umezu](https://anilist.co/staff/97777/Kazuo-Umezu), and [Leiji Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97597/Leiji-Matsumoto). Sadamoto would go on to author the Evangelion manga. 

Post-Gainax he has remained active as character designer, mostly for [Mamoru Hosoda](https://anilist.co/staff/100067/Mamoru-Hosoda)'s popular feature films. He has also focused on different visual and illustration works, as he worked on several manga and is co-creator and character designer for the .hack game franchise.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/y_sadamoto)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ShiroSAGISU_twi)

__Non-Anime Credits:__ 
- Music composer for ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' (N64, VG) (Japanese) 
- Music composer for ''Shining Force Neo'' (VG)
- Music composer for ''Attack on Titan (live-action movie)''
- Music composer for'' Attack on Titan II: End of the World (live-action movie)''
- Music composer for ''Shin Godzilla''
- Music composer for ''Shin Ultraman''

[Website](https://www.utadahikaru.jp/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChcgcbX3zMBwd0wTJyy2JlA) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/utadahikaru) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/kuma_power/)

Hikaru Utada is a Japanese-American singer-songwriter, composer and producer.

Born in the United States to Japanese parents, record producer Utada Teruzane and enka singer Keiko Fuji, Utada began to write music and lyrics at an early age and often traveled to Tokyo as a result of their father's job. Eventually, a recording contract with Toshiba-EMI was signed and, under the stage name Cubic U, Utada released their English-language debut album Precious in early 1998, but it was a commercial failure. In the following year, heavily influenced by R&B and dance-pop, their Japanese-language debut First Love was released and became an instant success. Backed by the massive success of singles "Automatic," "Time Will Tell," and "Movin' On Without You," the album sold two million copies in its first week in Japan, topped the Oricon charts for six non-consecutive weeks and went on to sell six million more throughout the rest of 1999. First Love eventually became the country's best-selling album of all time.

By the end of the '00s, Utada was deemed "the most influential artist of the decade" in the Japanese music landscape by The Japan Times. Utada's commercial success has made them one of Japan's top-selling recording artists of all time with over 37 million records sold since launching their career in the late '90s. Twelve of their singles have reached number-one on the Oricon Singles Chart, while ten of their albums have become chart-toppers. Six of their full-length releases are among the country's highest-selling albums of all time, including First Love, Distance and Deep River, which are among the top ten best-selling records of Japan's music history.

Utada has performed theme songs for all of the four [Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/2759/) reboot movies, as well as for [Freedom](https://anilist.co/anime/1747/) and [To Your Eternity](https://anilist.co/anime/114535/).

Additionally, they are also known by international audiences for writing and producing four theme-songs to the video game series Kingdom Hearts.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/tomoki_kyoda/)

Influenced by Hiroyuki Nakano's commercials and music videos, he studied video art at the Musashino Art University, joining Gento Matsumoto's company Sal Brunei as a graphic designer. He soon changed his occupation to the animation industry, having aspired to be an animation director since his childhood. 

He initially joined [Group TAC](https://anilist.co/studio/86/Group-TAC) where he worked as episode director and storyboard artist under the guidance of [Mitsuru Hongou](https://anilist.co/staff/103366/Mitsuru-Hongou). His first major role was as mechanical/creature designer on [Chikyuu Bouei Kazoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1962/The-Daichis--Earths-Defense-Family/), working alongside [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/Shouji-Kawamori) and [Kazutaka Miyatake](https://anilist.co/staff/100987/Kazutaka-Miyatake), with whom he would collaborate profusely afterwards. 

He later moved to studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/bones) landing as assistant director for [Yutaka Izubuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99075/Yutaka-Izubuchi)'s [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/RahXephon/). The two became close collaborators, with Kyouda soon taking the leading role on the [RahXephon: Pluralitas Concentio](https://anilist.co/anime/758/RahXephon-The-Motion-Picture/) movie.

Soon after, he directed [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/Eureka-Seven/), incorporating his love for music and different sub-cultures into mecha anime.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森山雄治) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuji_Moriyama) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/77356964)

Yuuji Moriyama is a director, animator and character designer.

Moriyama started helping out with in-between animation when he was a student at Kanto Daiichi High School. After graduating from high school, he joined Studio Musashi, which was recruiting staff through newspaper ads. His first work as an official in-betweener was for [Wakusei Robo Danguard Ace](https://anilist.co/anime/1986/). He then moved to Studio Cockpit, where he worked on [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/), before moving on to NeoMedia. There he worked on [Trider G7](https://anilist.co/anime/4536/), [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/), and [Belle and Sebastian](https://anilist.co/anime/3836/). With Trider G7, he was promoted from in-between to key animation. He left NeoMedia in 1982 to work as a freelancer, starting with [Combat Mecha Xabungle](https://anilist.co/anime/2254/) and [Makyou Densetsu Acrobunch](https://anilist.co/anime/3880/).

The popular anime [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), in which he participated from the same year, was Moriyama's breakthrough work. With this series, he made his debut as an animation director and storyboard artist, and was in charge of the opening animation for the first time, joining a group of popular animators overnight. Chief director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/), who was responsible for Urusei Yatsura, expected him to become a partner, so Moriyama tried his hand at manga as well by illustrating a manga written by Oshii that was serialized in the Animage magazine in 1984 called Todo no Tsumari. After the end of Urusei Yatsura, he was selected as a character designer for the later series [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/), and has since been in charge of character design for many other works. In 1987, he won the 4th Japan Anime Awards in the Animation Director category. After that, he shifted from animating to directing.
After that he participated in many works, mainly Chaos Project , Studio Pierrot , and Studio Hibari and then has seated at Studio Hibari's Lerche. 

Moriyama often works under one of his many pen-names.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴巻和哉)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴巻和哉)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴巻和哉)

Affiliated with [Studio Silver](https://anilist.co/studio/6240/). Older brother of [You Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/).

He is known for having reached great expertise in many techniques from realistic animation to digital compositing. This gives him the ability to have full control over his works, often being responsible for the key frames, in-betweens, finishing, photography and backgrounds of the scenes he is in charge of.

His skilled use of coloring and compositing, together with the realistic depiction of movement make his works to be often mistaken for computer generated animation.

**Notable works outside anime:**
~!
- Ghost in the Shell (Video Game, 1997) (OP Key Animation)
- Tales of Phantasia (Video Game, 1998) (Cutscene Director, Animation Director, Key Animation)
- Valkyrie Profile Series (Video Game, 1999-2008) (Character Design, Art Design) 
- Kafu ~Kono Shirabe ga Kimi ni Todokimasu You ni~ (Visual Novel, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography, CG Animation)
- Sakura Wars 3: Paris is Burning? (Video Game, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-Between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Akiiro Renka (Visual Novel, 2005) (OP Director, Animation Character Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Muv-Luv Alternative (Visual Novel, 2006) (Cutscene Mecha Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography) !~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/235154812) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/30949)

Started out as amateur gif animator before turning professional. He initially failed an examination test for [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) but was later scouted by the late [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100406/) for [Beck](https://anilist.co/anime/57/). There he met noted animators [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/), the former which he would work with on numerous occasions afterwards.

His breakthrough as an animator was on [Noein](https://anilist.co/anime/584/), a series directed by [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/). The 12th episode was highly regarded by animation fans and other animators for the given display by him and Matsumoto. He would later also serve as a character designer on [Birdy the Mighty: Decode](https://anilist.co/anime/3974/), another series directed by Akane.

His dedication for animation could also be seen on [The Girl Who Leapt Through Time](https://anilist.co/anime/2236/), for which he animated a minute-long scene of the main character running down a street. He went on the actual street in Tokyo to film himself for reference footage for the cut.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/本田雄)

After dropping out from Tokyo Designers' College in 1987, Honda joined Atelier Giga. He later joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/), where he debuted as the studio's youngest animation director on [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). A few years later in 1994, he got to handle the character designs for the first time on [Metal Fighter Miku](https://anilist.co/anime/1175/), a TV series directed by [Akiyuki Shinbou](https://anilist.co/staff/100089/).

After having left Gainax, Honda participated in most of [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/)'s works. Perhaps most notably as a character designer on [Millenium Actress](https://anilist.co/anime/1033/), a role which was originally planned to be [Hideki Hamasu](https://anilist.co/staff/125820/)'s, but was given to him due to Hamasu having contracted a severe tendon inflammation. Honda also designed the characters for [Mitsuo Iso](https://anilist.co/staff/100151/)'s [Dennou Coil](https://anilist.co/anime/2164/).

In 2006, Honda joined [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/) and reprised his vital staff roles in the [Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/2759/) franchise. The same year he made his long-awaited debut in a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) film, working as a key animator on [Tales from Earthsea](https://anilist.co/anime/1829/) and then again on [Ponyo](https://anilist.co/anime/2890/). His work received high praise by [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) for expressing the characters' individuality through their movements.

Nicknamed as "Master" (師匠, Shishou), by [Takahiro Kishida](https://anilist.co/staff/101403/) during the production of [Bubblegum Crisis](https://anilist.co/anime/1347/). Since then the nickname has been widely recognized within the industry.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sushio_) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sushiogumicompany/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%81%99%E3%81%97%E3%81%8A)

Ishizaki Toshio, better known as Sushio, is an animator, illustrator and character designer working for [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/).

After graduating from Yoyogi Animation Academy, he joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). He debuted as an in-betweener in [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/), as a key animator on [Berserk](https://anilist.co/anime/33/), and as an animation director on [Mahoromatic](https://anilist.co/anime/276/). In 2007, he served as a character designer for the first time on [Kiss Dum: Engage Planet](https://anilist.co/anime/2106/). He was a key staff member at Gainax for a long time, but left in 2011 when [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/) and others established the anime production company Trigger. There he was given the job of handling the character designs for [Kill la Kill](https://anilist.co/anime/18679/), the first TV series produced by the newly-found studio.

Specializes in action and effects, and his skills attract a lot of attention in the industry.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/828502878721421314)
Affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1178607902522654720)

Originating from Ad Cosmo. Frequent presence in the [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/2581/) franchise since 2007.
Affiliated with Deho Gallery.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/shinji_higuchi)

A notable director, special effects director and designer working on both tokusatsu and anime.

He started his career in 1984 working on Godzilla as a modeler for the monsters. The same year he joined Daicon Film, working on the special effects of the tokusatsu movie *Yamata no Orochi no Gyakushu*, and later became one of the founding members of [Studio Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/).

In 1992 he established Studio [GONZO](https://anilist.co/studio/3/) alongside other ex-Gainax staff [Shouji Murahama](https://anilist.co/staff/119708/), [Hiroshi Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97308/) and [Mahiro Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/100392/).

His most notable achievements in tokusatsu are working as special effects director for *Gamera: Guardian of the Universe* (1995), and as both special effects director and director, on *Shin Godzilla* (2016).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/213956842)

Affiliated with [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/213956842)

Affiliated with [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).
